system.description:
Often expensive, these upscale fountain pens provide a more personalized touch whether scribing spells, or writing notes or letters. A fountain pen has three parts that can each be customized in various ways: The Nib, which is the tip of the pen used to write with, the Body, which is the external shell of the pen which holds the other parts together, and the Reservoir, which is the part of the pen which actually holds the ink.

Experiencing a recent revival in popularity, these pens are also often given as gifts among white-collar professionals. A Premium fountain pen features a lacquered Darkwood Pen Body, a Fine or Medium Gold Nib, and a Piston Cartridge.

Nib: A medium nib creates a deeply colored line, but uses more ink than a fine nib. A medium nib can scribe only 70% as many Spells per fill as a fine nib, but gains +1 additional SP when using Spell Ink of the appropriate school, and a -4 additional penalty when using spell ink of an inappropriate school.

Nib Material: A traditional material, various gold alloys have been used for fountain pen nibs since their invention. Gold Nibs are more flexible than steel ones, adapting more readily to an individual’s writing style. Using a Gold Nib decreases the time it takes to scribe a spell by 2, rounded up to the nearest minute or Combat Point.

Body: Preferred by those seeking a more robust feel, the light weight of a darkwood pen body is nimble in the hand, while the grain of the wood provides a sure grip, which are both desirable features for a Stylus. When retrieving a fountain pen with a darkwood pen body from a pocket, bag, pouch, or MOLLE the CP cost is 3 less. When using a fountain pen with a darkwood pen body as a stylus, the CP cost to fire it is 1 less.

Reservoir: This Pen Cartridge holds enough ink to scribe up to 10 spells before needing to be refilled. The pen is refilled by suction caused by it’s internal piston.
